Subject: Ordering Test  _Output_ ?
Date: Mon, 02 Apr 2001 14:01:40 -0400
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F132MJ69ik6kvXsn2Yf00013d38@...>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 02 Apr 2001 18:01:40.0717 (UTC) FILETIME=[F80C81D0:01C0BB9E]
From: "Mathieu Gervais" <egoine_@...>

Hi,

I've been thinking about test order recently and I have an idea I would like 
to submit to people here just to know how bad it is :)

The idea is that often, event if the tests are unit tests, some are more 
basic than others. That is if test "basic1" doesn't pass, don't even expect 
test "lessbasic1" and test "lessbasic2" to pass. For example, in the 
MoneyTest example in the "Junit cookbook", testMoneyEquals is very basic and 
if that one fails, many tests will also fail. What my idea is about is *not* 
related to ordering the execution of the tests themselves. (I personnally 
believe they should de order-independant, the runners could even run them in 
a random order to ensure developpers make them independant.) The idea is 
about ordering the *test results*.

I personnally hate when suddenly 20 tests fails and I have to inspect all of 
that ouput to know where is possibly the problem. I would like an 
error/failure in testMoneyEquals() to show *first* in the output. How to 
implement this? The test writer could somehow specify a "level" for each 
test (basic, mid, complex). That could be totally optionnal and thus not 
change the current API. That would be *just a hint* from the test writer to 
the person running the tests saying "hey, look there first".

Personnally I'm not even sure it's worth it, but I wanted to share that idea 
with people on the list.

Mathieu

>From: Mike Clark Reply-To: junit@yahoogroups.com To: junit@yahoogroups.com 
>Subject: Re: AW: [junit] Ordered execution of test cases Date: Mon, 2 Apr 
>2001 07:16:49 -0700 (PDT)
[...]
>Agreed. They are executed in this order only because the underlying 
>collection is ordered - an implementation detail not to be depended upon. I 
>also agree that tests should be independent; however, the original poster 
>was aware of these recommendations and willing to accept the implications.
>
>Mike
